F16B22ED49AA46DEB210F383CBE0CDA1.description: Discuss the purpose of various dances in medieval times.

15AF41BC17D643BDBB223388EC17EC76.description: Observe a variety of dances found in Alberta.

1699CD68B1A84D39B7C0F62B890346E9.description: Discuss examples of knowledge that First Nations, Métis, and Inuit can share through dance.

6EF7B7F52DC94BAAB999F1FBE04BA928.description: Demonstrate how artistic roles and responsibilities contribute to a sense of community

98EC15A7CAB5464783FB21B17957CA56.description: Participate as a performer and an audience member in an artistic community.

3B2DE788796C441F9B865C2F85446E4B.description: Dances in the middle ages may have reflected religious beliefs.

B5A2EC23BF6640B8BD162D04CC791E7F.description: Culture was revealed through dances of the middle ages.

A26E730136FA4BCD81ED888062B18701.description: Dance in Alberta can reflect the culture of those who came before us and those who live here now

70A8C121DC3E40EC8BD8ADEC6B47338F.description: The culture of an artistic community is about shared ways of being together and reaching common goals.

CF5A0D6E307B457382F184F928E9A1A0.description: When communities unite through the arts, culture can be learned

10B5104CC9F94BF395CD00797169D8EA.description: Flamenco dance originated in India and was inspired to some extent by Arabic music and culture

BDCDA0F9FD1547B19C3AEE1B274018D8.description: The Silk Road provided a means for the spread of Islam to Spain and western Europe

0A6AF13E7BFE47BC82DAABEBC29660E2.description: Muslim dances included the Whirling Dervish, which is characterized by fast movements and spinning

163A813E8BE04001A1038E9BEBBCB2CA.description: During medieval times, Muslim men and women were divided into two groups for dancing: one for men and one for women

698EAA99EE1E434EB13E0C47388C4424.description:
Attitudes toward dance varied among different places within
medieval Muslim communities

B7630D23462E4223B7EB8C33B918E91A.description: Non-religious (secular) dance was a part of court life in many medieval kingdoms and could include dances that were a form of entertainment at gatherings dances that were a source of fun and relaxation for participants dances of the noble courts, which included Basse/Saltarello

9382B229E3114319A7DB33789D97D893.description: Religious (sacred) dances in medieval Europe were performed as part of rituals and ceremonies and can include liturgical dance as a form of movement used to pray and worship May dances performed on May 1 or during mid-summer celebrations Dance of Death, known as the Dance Macabre dance epidemics, such as the Tarantella, were performed with the belief that it could cure diseases

ACE09277BB2A42669B33285F3F282A39.description: The Catholic Church in medieval Europe disapproved of certain kinds of dance, including pagan dances

290EE0811323409DB9606723687EDB1D.description: Common dances performed in medieval Europe can include Midsummer Night's Eve dance the roundel, a slow dance performed in a circle the carole, a circle dance performed in mid-summer festivals the farandole, a lively dance where dancers form a chain by linking hands the cushion dance, where a dancer drops a cushion in front of a dance partner as an invitation to dance

64C1750CB2EF4A179BBF80005573A916.description: Pagan dances were performed in relation to rituals or ceremonies that celebrated gods

4B6931C30ECC4C2C997A8CE855B080F3.description: Dances in Alberta can reflect the history and traditions of communities and other areas of the world and can include French-Canadian dances Ukrainian dance Irish dance

5B67C97BBDC84C5CB44634D2E4F382A1.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit dances can reflect the history and traditions of communities that are indigenous to Alberta

0ED5627BB6A64E21A2BD5F2C18D1797A.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit dance is holistic in nature and can have individual and collective benefits, including social well-being physical health spiritual connection emotional and mental well-being intellectual development

3C8014BCA2DF48B7BE43BB3A5516BD12.description: First Nations, Métis, and Inuit dance can represent cultural stories and traditions show gratitude and reverence demonstrate reciprocity mimic elements of the natural world, including animals and water reflect spirituality contribute to healing

551FCF7FD7F84EEF8DDC4E7EDA28DAB2.description: Perspectives can be developed by experiencing the dances of other individuals, including folk dance and social dance

4CF20D026A5943E487726F897C1EC601.description: The culture of an artistic community can support the caring and respectful inclusion of all participants

D39B2A5EB7AE417DAD2B93187C213E24.description: Vocabulary related to dance can be used to objectively describe movement

DC01D30C8CCE4BD2A92AE07BDC7645C0.description: Culture can be enhanced when members of a dance community participate, communicate, engage, and share responsibilities.

420969C311734179A36C2FD9D3ACE110.description: Students relate how culture is reflected in dance across various times and places

E49472FFDEBC4E028FDCC5CD00EA6C7B.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in dance can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great works of dance, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate.

1F67F8D6950F4BCFB1DABC13777CB6A9.description: Respond to various auditory, visual, or physical cues when dancing

DE3CE929F71B4395881A1D341EA0FB96.description: Discuss solutions to movement problems encountered when representing a narrative in dance

FBEA88FB6ECC4A8F9EB46312D246AB25.description: Make artistic choices when exploring how to represent narrative in dance

45D97A9B86494C678707EF0DE05D5D90.description: Collaborate with others when generating and representing a narrative through dance

A68A3E6B91CE47D78D487252BEAC5456.description: Share and replicate movement ideas with others.

F2E91A4F1356474C8E4EC0580143934A.description: Create movement patterns that reflect a point of view or perspective.

BDFD72086EB140769E2F4B0F79D77058.description: Create movement patterns or phrases that can illustrate a part of a narrative

201DB9D94F624839BD7CBB20243DD295.description: Construct a narrative based on an inspiration

F94FF92418AD443CA85B766A8D4488C6.description: Experiment with various ways to structure a narrative in dance

ACEB76CE8AA5456AB9F760617859C29E.description: A narrative in dance can be shaped by the dancer or ensemble.

8CA8B7800B074F409FADD18B0D2BAB07.description: The way in which the elements of dance are applied to movement can convey ideas, feelings, and perspectives.

C96FACE350594D10B788629E41685FAB.description: A narrative can communicate points of view or perspectives of an individual or group

B120C4DBD01D4D05A1AC9D2FD143E949.description: A narrative can be factual or fictitious.

591E14F2DAC944198D347E7DF7DD9E49.description: A narrative in dance can be illustrated as a partial or whole representation

319492F806BA4E4E98DE3D24B7565F66.description: Expression of a narrative in dance can be refined by applying creative processes

31705EB975754565B32E91866C556829.description: Physical cues can be given in dance through focus, facial expressions, and contact with other dancers

0099FDB15E12455DB9AFADD61A518E71.description: Visual cues can include the use of formations, pathways, and directions

0361C2EFED12437CB20F30B4105CAFB3.description: Auditory cues can be given by the teacher or choreographer and can include movement directions feedback in the moment counting beats aloud directing when to start or stop a movement or dance

3842C5E5964E460ABDD486E95E113A40.description: Auditory, physical, or visual cues can direct when movements for a narrative begin or end.

379974DD229F4670A91F39B3F1E76C85.description: Narrative in dance can be enhanced by demonstrating the relationship between a dancer and the movement of others, including meeting and parting a dancer and the music a dancer and an object

80CC4FDB26624ED58F242BDA7E4D37FE.description: A dancer and ensemble can shape a narrative through their movements, reactions, thoughts, and ideas

3262723D17994B5CA3CB24F104FDFFB7.description: Facial expressions, body posture, and movement can contribute to how a narrative is expressed in dance

83787A8C32684DA69F9D784D8D2B3687.description: Force can intensify, elaborate, or highlight the way that movements communicate perspectives, ideas, or feelings

E3C8AA42D62A4262B6A74E63AAD4E06C.description: Points of view or perspectives can reflect ideas or knowledge feelings experiences culture beliefs

1001528D86034E7B8CC19F299BD180FB.description: Inspiration for a narrative may come from a variety of sources.

59EB4AB1B1E04D63895BF3790ED431CC.description: Choreographic forms can give structure to a narrative, including AB (binary form) ABA (ternary form) ABC (suite), which has three contrasting sections narrative that follows a storyline

E15C06F284BB404D8718E3A59279856F.description: A narrative can be structured using various dance styles, which can include ballet creative dance folk and social dance

D7D26100E9DF47DD8845715BDD315AE5.description: The elements of dance can be used to structure a narrative through movement patterns or phrases an entire dance stillness, including tableau, where bodies create shapes to create an image

F5C1BAEA38A140FDBFABEFB17E012C5B.description: A narrative in dance may or may not represent a sequence of events in the order in which they happened.

84C4CE6EA99540A0BFDC20AA37EA581D.description: Students use narrative as a structure for organizing movements in dance

88507F3420C64BAD911609431A363B8E.description: Creating and presenting: Ideas can be represented through movement and dance that draw upon foundational knowledge

6B04367A31CE49CC8B372793A5E4714E.description: Participate in regular warm-ups and cool-downs in dance

02CC6C060A3642C59C43C482552ED19E.description: Recognize the role of muscle contraction in executing certain movements

27E175632AB9430FAFAD874EB29D7A0E.description: Experience various dance styles that use sustained and percussive flows of energy

1CE962F8F5064D44856A67E231D28365.description: Describe how force can be used to highlight a movement

5AE272BCFB1A465299C72594747B135A.description: Explore how to isolate force to specific body parts.

313FBC2115854B8AAEFF9DBC7789FB14.description: Experiment with bound-flow and free-flow movements.

1ACF513C694241A69794CADF5208A714.description: Identify the amount of force the body requires for certain movements.

3F91B486F9684791A7F941F91F9601CA.description: Use dance vocabulary to describe the quality of a movement when force is applied.

B3400FD438434DBBA59D1C35295FACD8.description: Explore movements that require passive or active weight

4E24320D4A194B90AA82A209AD5E3BE4.description: Combine weight, energy, and speed in the exploration of movement possibilities

AE12C1A1516D4DBEA35D04879C47A965.description: Observe how force can be used to support the weight of others.

D4C8C779CEB443E4B95E3178B96C7714.description: Sustain a steady beat when executing movement patterns

50D1F64B82504E40A49AFB81EFDB8BE0.description: Recognize the timing required to successfully execute movements in unison or sequentially.

C2779F8A5CDC4208B24590FE5000C1A3.description: Identify how accents can be illustrated using movement

99A07659771841328CA4671E38043DA0.description: Experience how changes in tempo, metre, or accent may influence the duration of a movement

D27CD0AF3B474ED6BEA70972C1CD2B2C.description: Observe a variety of styles and genres of dance to experience how a dancer moves in relation to tempo, metre, accent, or rhythm

F3B77B44892942699D321A7621493FD9.description: Explore various stimuli as a means to direct movement

BE489CB5780943FEB2B117F70325FF9C.description: Apply movements to the rhythm of music or spoken texts

2CB85DE0CB3C427BBE1158B3A48E3415.description: Identify how the duration of a movement can be influenced by force or speed

0FCF9F30172D4A1FBAAEA4CE254EC512.description: Discuss how the duration of a movement can create meaning

BBF730402D8D466A9E518553E5B4102D.description: Combine movement phrases or patterns of varying durations to form a movement sequence

02881C4FABA24E70BF07853FF26621BF.description: Demonstrate how to begin and end a movement pattern or phrase within an allotted time

4A13C1B937914C36896ECCDB213E8EF5.description: Force is not visible, but its effects can be observed through movement

4EC12DE611374885BC61165EC9C6F5A1.description: Force is the push-pull relationship between a dancer and gravity

74FABCD64AD7411FAA5E207012FC4EE9.description: Time can determine how a dancer moves in relation to a tempo, a metre, an accent, or a rhythm

2512BBBE35AB4894A3491AE2DEC2F2ED.description: Time is the duration of a movement or dance

4D66CA8DC9B642F08A984E8D6728BF5B.description: Sustained flow is seen in movements that are slow, smooth, continuous, and even

3FCDCC6B80914FA8A50F229F2216C5DF.description: Percussive flow is seen in movements that have sharp, sudden, and short bursts of energy

B7090B409EA44FC7AADA4B6F61AA4DB8.description: Force is used in movement through sustained and percussive flow

D57E3FC8E6E448C58A4857862917A022.description: When applied to movement, force can highlight or reinforce parts of a movement, pattern, or phrase

377F676337E64410B3218E426F75BD6E.description: Warm-ups and cool-downs assist in preparing the body for dance

90E291A400D04AF4A8A526E9AC515265.description: The contraction of muscles is required to execute movement and maintain balance in dance

B63F48346D254324B078FDDA87177AE2.description: Force is felt in the muscles and is engaged by contracting the muscles.

19AF35546C734E5CB9C9A6713EE005F2.description: Force, as an element of dance, can create flow movements described as bound-flow movements, which are rigid and can be stopped easily free-flow movements, which are fluid and not easily stopped

BE30AD6939224103ACD58A83D77FB4FF.description: Force requires muscle strength to execute certain movements or to support the weight of another dancer

6F2638D450B94BDFA11A83130A84ED59.description: Varying the weight and speed of movements creates various movement energies, including sharp smooth swingy, involving a drop into gravity, including swing, sway, or rock shaky, which creates force through vibratory movements, including wiggle, vibrate, or bounce

2A00BAE442A64D63BDE4EE61428AA147.description: Weight can be described as passive or heavy, when the body gives into gravity active and energetic movement against gravity

0827D0B4BABF47DF81C0FC7324112335.description: Energy of movements, including smooth, swingy, shaky, and sharp qualities, can be executed with weight and speed.

8393F38B641241B197AC5AEFA93CE345.description: Force influences the quality of a movement when energy, weight, and flow of movement are applied

4BCA96ABFB034D7587C4FDDC11CBA363.description: Movement and timing can vary across styles of dance, including jazz ballet hip hop social dance folk dance

A6D3897D3B294A7999A3087B4186C654.description: Dance steps may have specific movements and timing, as seen in the basic triple step, including waltz (has a slow-quick-quick step pattern), polka (has a quick-quick-slow step pattern), schottische (three steps and a hop)

2D8CFE87E4C54CCA952102644C3B1C08.description: Timing refers to moving to the beat of the music and moving in relation to other dancers, including before or after one another in unison

109F7CBB8D6F4A1591B079E7193C3D71.description: Auditory stimuli can influence how a dancer moves, including music spoken text instrument sounds vocal sounds

A21607CEFCA444AF9CC8EC6DC5483838.description: The duration of a dance usually has a relationship to the duration of auditory stimuli that accompany it.

CB28FA22004945DA9A5609B5E3E70A0B.description: Duration of a movement can create meaning in dance.

04CECCA8DB2D46F2857B0B09F95E821B.description: The speed of a movement can be performed quickly for a short time slowly for a long time to gradually get faster to gradually get slower

6A3F4AB244464B55A8F832C840C1B084.description: Duration of a movement, phrase, pattern, or dance, can be short, long, or medium and include pauses and stillness.

C7C5B76C94B54947A6691F6BA80C3687.description: Duration of a movement can change when force or speed is applied

1C8F895749A44AEEA1A57D076D9F0B93.description: Time can determine when a movement begins or ends

235BE78759D346E7B7162DC3959C17EB.description: Students analyze time and force in relation to the elements of dance

3D1130F4FE0949E399DE2E65AAF6622B.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Dance literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles
